column2: Then the king went into the chamber unto Sir Tramtrist, and then was he gone unto his chamber, and the king found him all ready armed to mount upon his horse.
column3: Then the king went into the chamber unto Sir Tramtrist, and then was he gone unto his chamber, and the king found him all ready armed to mount upon his horse.

column2: When the king saw him all ready armed to go unto horseback, the king said: Nay, Tramtrist, it will not avail to compare thee against me; but thus much I shall do for my worship and for thy love; in so much as thou art within my court it were no worship for me to slay thee: therefore upon this condition I will give thee leave for to depart from this court in safety, so thou wilt tell me who was thy father, and what is thy name, and if thou slew Sir Marhaus, my brother.
column3: When the king saw him all ready armed to go unto horseback, the king said: Nay, Tramtrist, it will not avail to compare thee against me; but thus much I shall do for my worship and for thy love; in so much as thou art within my court it were no worship for me to slay thee: therefore upon this condition I will give thee leave for to depart from this court in safety, so thou wilt tell me who was thy father, and what is thy name, and if thou slew Sir Marhaus, my brother.

column2: CHAPTER XII.
column3: CHAPTER twelve.

column2: How Sir Tristram departed from the king and La Beale Isoud out of Ireland for to come into Cornwall.
column3: How Sir Tristram departed from the king and La Beale Isoud out of Ireland for to come into Cornwall.

column2: SIR, said Tristram, now I shall tell you all the truth: my father's name is Sir Meliodas, King of Liones, and my mother hight Elizabeth, that was sister unto King Mark of Cornwall; and my mother died of me in the forest, and because thereof she commanded, or she died, that when I were christened they should christen me Tristram; and because I would not be known in this country I turned my name and let me call Tramtrist; and for the truage of Cornwall I fought for my eme's sake, and for the right of Cornwall that ye had posseded many years.
column3: SIR, said Tristram, now I shall tell you all the truth: my father's name is Sir Meliodas, King of Liones, and my mother hight Elizabeth, that was sister unto King Mark of Cornwall; and my mother died of me in the forest, and because thereof she commanded, or she died, that when I were christened they should christen me Tristram; and because I would not be known in this country I turned my name and let me call Tramtrist; and for the truage of Cornwall I fought for my eme's sake, and for the right of Cornwall that ye had posseded many years.

column2: And wit ye well, said Tristram unto the king, I did the battle for the love of mine uncle, King Mark, and for the love of the country of Cornwall, and for to increase mine honour; for that same day that I fought with Sir Marhaus I was made knight, and never or then did I battle with no knight, and from me he went alive, and left his shield and his sword behind.
column3: And wit ye well, said Tristram unto the king, I did the battle for the love of mine uncle, King Mark, and for the love of the country of Cornwall, and for to increase mine honour; for that same day that I fought with Sir Marhaus I was made knight, and never or then did I battle with no knight, and from me he went alive, and left his shield and his sword behind.

column2: So God me help, said the king, I may not say but ye did as a knight should, and it was your part to do for your quarrel, and to increase your worship as a knight should; howbeit I may not maintain you in this country with my worship, unless that I should displease my barons, and my wife and her kin.
column3: So God me help, said the king, I may not say but ye did as a knight should, and it was your part to do for your quarrel, and to increase your worship as a knight should; howbeit I may not maintain you in this country with my worship, unless that I should displease my barons, and my wife and her kin.

column2: Sir, said Tristram, I thank you of your good lordship that I have had with you here, and the great goodness my lady, your daughter, hath shewed me, and therefore, said Sir Tristram, it may so happen that ye shall win more by my life than by my death, for in the parts of England it may happen I may do you service at some season, that ye shall be glad that ever ye shewed me your good lordship.
column3: Sir, said Tristram, I thank you of your good lordship that I have had with you here, and the great goodness my lady, your daughter, hath shewed me, and therefore, said Sir Tristram, it may so happen that ye shall win more by my life than by my death, for in the parts of England it may happen I may do you service at some season, that ye shall be glad that ever ye shewed me your good lordship.

column2: With more I promise you as I am true knight, that in all places I shall be my lady your daughter's servant and knight in right and in wrong, and I shall never fail her, to do as much as a knight may do.
column3: With more I promise you as I am true knight, that in all places I shall be my lady your daughter's servant and knight in right and in wrong, and I shall never fail her, to do as much as a knight may do.

column2: Also I beseech your good grace that I may take my leave at my lady, your daughter, and at all the barons and knights.
column3: Also I beseech your good grace that I may take my leave at my lady, your daughter, and at all the barons and knights.

column2: I will well, said the king.
column3: I will well, said the king.

column2: Then Sir Tristram went unto La Beale Isoud and took his leave of her. And then he told her all, what he was, and how he had changed his name because he would not be known, and how a lady told him that he should never be whole till he came into this country where the poison was made, wherethrough I was near my death had not your ladyship been.
column3: Then Sir Tristram went unto La Beale Isoud and took his leave of her. And then he told her all, what he was, and how he had changed his name because he would not be known, and how a lady told him that he should never be whole till he came into this country where the poison was made, wherethrough I was near my death had not your ladyship been.

column2: O gentle knight, said La Beale Isoud, full woe am I of thy departing, for I saw never man that I owed so good will to.
column3: O gentle knight, said La Beale Isoud, full woe am I of thy departing, for I saw never man that I owed so good will to.

column2: And therewithal she wept heartily.
column3: And therewithal she wept heartily.

column2: Madam, said Sir Tristram, ye shall understand that my name is Sir Tristram de Liones, gotten of King Meliodas, and born of his queen. And I promise you faithfully that I shall be all the days of my life your knight.
column3: Madam, said Sir Tristram, ye shall understand that my name is Sir Tristram de Liones, gotten of King Meliodas, and born of his queen. And I promise you faithfully that I shall be all the days of my life your knight.

column2: Gramercy, said La Beale Isoud, and I promise you there-against that I shall not be married this seven years but by your assent; and to whom that ye will I shall be married to him will I have, and he will have me if ye will consent.
column3: Gramercy, said La Beale Isoud, and I promise you there against that I shall not be married this seven years but by your assent; and to whom that ye will I shall be married to him will I have, and he will have me if ye will consent.

column2: And then Sir Tristram gave her a ring, and she gave him another; and therewith he departed from her, leaving her making great dole and lamentation; and he straight went unto the court among all the barons, and there he took his leave at most and least, and openly he said among them all: Fair lords, now it is so that I must depart: if there be any man here that I have offended unto, or that any man be with me grieved, let complain him here afore me or that ever I depart, and I shall amend it unto my power.
column3: And then Sir Tristram gave her a ring, and she gave him another; and therewith he departed from her, leaving her making great dole and lamentation; and he straight went unto the court among all the barons, and there he took his leave at most and least, and openly he said among them all: Fair lords, now it is so that I must depart: if there be any man here that I have offended unto, or that any man be with me grieved, let complain him here afore me or that ever I depart, and I shall amend it unto my power.

column2: And if there be any that will proffer me wrong, or say of me wrong or shame behind my back, say it now or never, and here is my body to make it good, body against body.
column3: And if there be any that will proffer me wrong, or say of me wrong or shame behind my back, say it now or never, and here is my body to make it good, body against body.

column2: And all they stood still, there was not one that would say one word; yet were there some knights that were of the queen's blood, and of Sir Marhaus' blood, but they would not meddle with him.
column3: And all they stood still, there was not one that would say one word; yet were there some knights that were of the queen's blood, and of Sir Marhaus' blood, but they would not meddle with him.

column2: CHAPTER XIII.
column3: CHAPTER thirteen.

column2: How Sir Tristram and King Mark hurted each other for the love of a knight's wife.
column3: How Sir Tristram and King Mark hurted each other for the love of a knight's wife.

column2: SO Sir Tristram departed, and took the sea, and with good wind he arrived up at Tintagil in Cornwall; and when King Mark was whole in his prosperity there came tidings that Sir Tristram was arrived, and whole of his wounds: thereof was King Mark passing glad, and so were all the barons; and when he saw his time he rode unto his father, King Meliodas, and there he had all the cheer that the king and the queen could make him.
column3: SO Sir Tristram departed, and took the sea, and with good wind he arrived up at Tintagil in Cornwall; and when King Mark was whole in his prosperity there came tidings that Sir Tristram was arrived, and whole of his wounds: thereof was King Mark passing glad, and so were all the barons; and when he saw his time he rode unto his father, King Meliodas, and there he had all the cheer that the king and the queen could make him.

column2: And then largely King Meliodas and his queen departed of their lands and goods to Sir Tristram.
column3: And then largely King Meliodas and his queen departed of their lands and goods to Sir Tristram.

column2: Then by the license of King Meliodas, his father, he returned again unto the court of King Mark, and there he lived in great joy long time, until at the last there befell a jealousy and an unkindness betwixt King Mark and Sir Tristram, for they loved both one lady.
column3: Then by the license of King Meliodas, his father, he returned again unto the court of King Mark, and there he lived in great joy long time, until at the last there befell a jealousy and an unkindness betwixt King Mark and Sir Tristram, for they loved both one lady.

column2: And she was an earl's wife that hight Sir Segwarides.
column3: And she was an earl's wife that hight Sir Segwarides.

column2: And this lady loved Sir Tristram passingly well.
column3: And this lady loved Sir Tristram passingly well.

column2: And he loved her again, for she was a passing fair lady, and that espied Sir Tristram well.
column3: And he loved her again, for she was a passing fair lady, and that espied Sir Tristram well.

column2: Then King Mark understood that and was jealous, for King Mark loved her passingly well.
column3: Then King Mark understood that and was jealous, for King Mark loved her passingly well.

column2: So it fell upon a day this lady sent a dwarf unto Sir Tristram, and bade him, as he loved her, that he would be with her the night next following.
column3: So it fell upon a day this lady sent a dwarf unto Sir Tristram, and bade him, as he loved her, that he would be with her the night next following.

column2: Also she charged you that ye come not to her but if ye be well armed, for her lover was called a good knight.
column3: Also she charged you that ye come not to her but if ye be well armed, for her lover was called a good knight.

column2: Sir Tristram answered to the dwarf: Recommend me unto my lady, and tell her I will not fail but I will be with her the term that she hath set me.
column3: Sir Tristram answered to the dwarf: Recommend me unto my lady, and tell her I will not fail but I will be with her the term that she hath set me.

column2: And with this answer the dwarf departed.
column3: And with this answer the dwarf departed.

column2: And King Mark espied that the dwarf was with Sir Tristram upon message from Segwarides' wife; then King Mark sent for the dwarf, and when he was come he made the dwarf by force to tell him all, why and wherefore that he came on message from Sir Tristram.
column3: And King Mark espied that the dwarf was with Sir Tristram upon message from Segwarides' wife; then King Mark sent for the dwarf, and when he was come he made the dwarf by force to tell him all, why and wherefore that he came on message from Sir Tristram.

column2: Now, said King Mark, go where thou wilt, and upon pain of death that thou say no word that thou spakest with me; so the dwarf departed from the king.
column3: Now, said King Mark, go where thou wilt, and upon pain of death that thou say no word that thou spakest with me; so the dwarf departed from the king.

column2: And that same night that the steven was set betwixt Segwarides' wife and Sir Tristram, King Mark armed him, and made him ready, and took two knights of his counsel with him; and so he rode afore for to abide by the way for to wait upon Sir Tristram.
column3: And that same night that the steven was set betwixt Segwarides' wife and Sir Tristram, King Mark armed him, and made him ready, and took two knights of his counsel with him; and so he rode afore for to abide by the way for to wait upon Sir Tristram.

column2: And as Sir Tristram came riding upon his way with his spear in his hand, King Mark came hurtling upon him with his two knights suddenly.
column3: And as Sir Tristram came riding upon his way with his spear in his hand, King Mark came hurtling upon him with his two knights suddenly.

column2: And all three smote him with their spears, and King Mark hurt Sir Tristram on the breast right sore.
column3: And all three smote him with their spears, and King Mark hurt Sir Tristram on the breast right sore.

column2: And then Sir Tristram feutred his spear, and smote his uncle, King Mark, so sore, that he rashed him to the earth, and bruised him that he lay still in a swoon, and long it was or ever he might wield himself.
column3: And then Sir Tristram feutred his spear, and smote his uncle, King Mark, so sore, that he rashed him to the earth, and bruised him that he lay still in a swoon, and long it was or ever he might wield himself.

column2: And then he ran to the one knight, and eft to the other, and smote them to the cold earth, that they lay still.
column3: And then he ran to the one knight, and eft to the other, and smote them to the cold earth, that they lay still.

column2: And therewithal Sir Tristram rode forth sore wounded to the lady, and found her abiding him at a postern.
column3: And therewithal Sir Tristram rode forth sore wounded to the lady, and found her abiding him at a postern.

column2: CHAPTER XIV.
column3: CHAPTER fourteen.

column2: How Sir Tristram lay with the lady, and how her husband fought with Sir Tristram.
column3: How Sir Tristram lay with the lady, and how her husband fought with Sir Tristram.

column2: AND there she welcomed him fair, and either halsed other in arms, and so she let put up his horse in the best wise, and then she unarmed him.
column3: AND there she welcomed him fair, and either halsed other in arms, and so she let put up his horse in the best wise, and then she unarmed him.

column2: And so they supped lightly, and went to bed with great joy and pleasaunce; and so in his raging he took no keep of his green wound that King Mark had given him.
column3: And so they supped lightly, and went to bed with great joy and pleasaunce; and so in his raging he took no keep of his green wound that King Mark had given him.

column2: And so Sir Tristram be-bled both the over sheet and the nether, and pillows, and head sheet.
column3: And so Sir Tristram be bled both the over sheet and the nether, and pillows, and head sheet.

column2: And within a while there came one afore, that warned her that her lord was near-hand within a bow-draught. So she made Sir Tristram to arise, and so he armed him, and took his horse, and so departed.
column3: And within a while there came one afore, that warned her that her lord was near hand within a bow draught. So she made Sir Tristram to arise, and so he armed him, and took his horse, and so departed.

column2: By then was come Segwarides, her lord, and when he found her bed troubled and broken, and went near and beheld it by candle light, then he saw that there had lain a wounded knight. Ah, false traitress, then he said, why hast thou betrayed me?
column3: By then was come Segwarides, her lord, and when he found her bed troubled and broken, and went near and beheld it by candle light, then he saw that there had lain a wounded knight. Ah, false traitress, then he said, why hast thou betrayed me?

column2: And therewithal he swang out a sword, and said: But if thou tell me who hath been here, here thou shalt die.
column3: And therewithal he swang out a sword, and said: But if thou tell me who hath been here, here thou shalt die.

column2: Ah, my lord, mercy, said the lady, and held up her hands, saying: Slay me not, and I shall tell you all who hath been here.
column3: Ah, my lord, mercy, said the lady, and held up her hands, saying: Slay me not, and I shall tell you all who hath been here.

column2: Tell anon, said Segwarides, to me all the truth.
column3: Tell anon, said Segwarides, to me all the truth.

column2: Anon for dread she said: Here was Sir Tristram with me, and by the way as he came to me ward, he was sore wounded.
column3: Anon for dread she said: Here was Sir Tristram with me, and by the way as he came to me ward, he was sore wounded.

column2: Ah, false traitress, said Segwarides, where is he become?
column3: Ah, false traitress, said Segwarides, where is he become?

column2: Sir, she said, he is armed, and departed on horseback, not yet hence half a mile.
column3: Sir, she said, he is armed, and departed on horseback, not yet hence half a mile.

column2: Ye say well, said Segwarides.
column3: Ye say well, said Segwarides.

column2: Then he armed him lightly, and gat his horse, and rode after Sir Tristram that rode straightway unto Tintagil.
column3: Then he armed him lightly, and gat his horse, and rode after Sir Tristram that rode straightway unto Tintagil.

column2: And within a while he overtook Sir Tristram, and then he bade him, Turn, false traitor knight. And Sir Tristram anon turned him against him.
column3: And within a while he overtook Sir Tristram, and then he bade him, Turn, false traitor knight. And Sir Tristram anon turned him against him.

column2: And therewithal Segwarides smote Sir Tristram with a spear that it all to-brast; and then he swang out his sword and smote fast at Sir Tristram.
column3: And therewithal Segwarides smote Sir Tristram with a spear that it all to brast; and then he swang out his sword and smote fast at Sir Tristram.

column2: Sir knight, said Sir Tristram, I counsel you that ye smite no more, howbeit for the wrongs that I have done you I will forbear you as long as I may.
column3: Sir knight, said Sir Tristram, I counsel you that ye smite no more, howbeit for the wrongs that I have done you I will forbear you as long as I may.

column2: Nay, said Segwarides, that shall not be, for either thou shalt die or I.
column3: Nay, said Segwarides, that shall not be, for either thou shalt die or i

column2: Then Sir Tristram drew out his sword, and hurtled his horse unto him fiercely, and through the waist of the body he smote Sir Segwarides that he fell to the earth in a swoon.
column3: Then Sir Tristram drew out his sword, and hurtled his horse unto him fiercely, and through the waist of the body he smote Sir Segwarides that he fell to the earth in a swoon.

column2: And so Sir Tristram departed and left him there.
column3: And so Sir Tristram departed and left him there.

column2: And so he rode unto Tintagil and took his lodging secretly, for he would not be known that he was hurt.
column3: And so he rode unto Tintagil and took his lodging secretly, for he would not be known that he was hurt.

column2: Also Sir Segwarides' men rode after their master, whom they found lying in the field sore wounded, and brought him home on his shield, and there he lay long or that he were whole, but at the last he recovered.
column3: Also Sir Segwarides' men rode after their master, whom they found lying in the field sore wounded, and brought him home on his shield, and there he lay long or that he were whole, but at the last he recovered.

column2: Also King Mark would not be aknown of that Sir Tristram and he had met that night.
column3: Also King Mark would not be aknown of that Sir Tristram and he had met that night.

column2: And as for Sir Tristram, he knew not that King Mark had met with him.
column3: And as for Sir Tristram, he knew not that King Mark had met with him.

column2: And so the king askance came to Sir Tristram, to comfort him as he lay sick in his bed.
column3: And so the king askance came to Sir Tristram, to comfort him as he lay sick in his bed.

column2: But as long as King Mark lived he loved never Sir Tristram after that; though there was fair speech, love was there none.
column3: But as long as King Mark lived he loved never Sir Tristram after that; though there was fair speech, love was there none.

column2: And thus it passed many weeks and days, and all was forgiven and forgotten; for Sir Segwarides durst not have ado with Sir Tristram, because of his noble prowess, and also because he was nephew unto King Mark; therefore he let it overslip: for he that hath a privy hurt is loath to have a shame outward.
column3: And thus it passed many weeks and days, and all was forgiven and forgotten; for Sir Segwarides durst not have ado with Sir Tristram, because of his noble prowess, and also because he was nephew unto King Mark; therefore he let it overslip: for he that hath a privy hurt is loath to have a shame outward.

column2: CHAPTER XV.
column3: CHAPTER fifteen.

column2: How Sir Bleoberis demanded the fairest lady in King Mark's court, whom he took away, and how he was fought with.
column3: How Sir Bleoberis demanded the fairest lady in King Mark's court, whom he took away, and how he was fought with.

column2: THEN it befell upon a day that the good knight Bleoberis de Ganis, brother to Blamore de Ganis, and nigh cousin unto the good knight Sir Launcelot du Lake, this Bleoberis came unto the court of King Mark, and there he asked of King Mark a boon, to give him what gift that he would ask in his court.
column3: THEN it befell upon a day that the good knight Bleoberis de Ganis, brother to Blamore de Ganis, and nigh cousin unto the good knight Sir Launcelot du Lake, this Bleoberis came unto the court of King Mark, and there he asked of King Mark a boon, to give him what gift that he would ask in his court.

column2: When the king heard him ask so, he marvelled of his asking, but because he was a knight of the Round Table, and of a great renown, King Mark granted him his whole asking.
column3: When the king heard him ask so, he marvelled of his asking, but because he was a knight of the Round Table, and of a great renown, King Mark granted him his whole asking.

column2: Then, said Sir Bleoberis, I will have the fairest lady in your court that me list to choose.
column3: Then, said Sir Bleoberis, I will have the fairest lady in your court that me list to choose.

column2: I may not say nay, said King Mark; now choose at your adventure. And so Sir Bleoberis did choose Sir Segwarides' wife, and took her by the hand, and so went his way with her; and so he took his horse and gart set her behind his squire, and rode upon his way.
column3: I may not say nay, said King Mark; now choose at your adventure. And so Sir Bleoberis did choose Sir Segwarides' wife, and took her by the hand, and so went his way with her; and so he took his horse and gart set her behind his squire, and rode upon his way.

column2: When Sir Segwarides heard tell that his lady was gone with a knight of King Arthur's court, then he armed him and rode after that knight for to rescue his lady.
column3: When Sir Segwarides heard tell that his lady was gone with a knight of King Arthur's court, then he armed him and rode after that knight for to rescue his lady.

column2: So when Bleoberis was gone with this lady, King Mark and all the court was wroth that she was away.
column3: So when Bleoberis was gone with this lady, King Mark and all the court was wroth that she was away.

column2: Then were there certain ladies that knew that there were great love between Sir Tristram and her, and also that lady loved Sir Tristram above all other knights.
column3: Then were there certain ladies that knew that there were great love between Sir Tristram and her, and also that lady loved Sir Tristram above all other knights.

column2: Then there was one lady that rebuked Sir Tristram in the horriblest wise, and called him coward knight, that he would for shame of his knighthood see a lady so shamefully be taken away from his uncle's court.
column3: Then there was one lady that rebuked Sir Tristram in the horriblest wise, and called him coward knight, that he would for shame of his knighthood see a lady so shamefully be taken away from his uncle's court.

column2: But she meant that either of them had loved other with entire heart.
column3: But she meant that either of them had loved other with entire heart.

column2: But Sir Tristram answered her thus: Fair lady, it is not my part to have ado in such matters while her lord and husband is present here; and if it had been that her lord had not been here in this court, then for the worship of this court peradventure I would have been her champion, and if so be Sir Segwarides speed not well, it may happen that I will speak with that good knight or ever he pass from this country.
column3: But Sir Tristram answered her thus: Fair lady, it is not my part to have ado in such matters while her lord and husband is present here; and if it had been that her lord had not been here in this court, then for the worship of this court peradventure I would have been her champion, and if so be Sir Segwarides speed not well, it may happen that I will speak with that good knight or ever he pass from this country.

column2: Then within a while came one of Sir Segwarides' squires, and told in the court that Sir Segwarides was beaten sore and wounded to the point of death; as he would have rescued his lady Sir Bleoberis overthrew him and sore hath wounded him.
column3: Then within a while came one of Sir Segwarides' squires, and told in the court that Sir Segwarides was beaten sore and wounded to the point of death; as he would have rescued his lady Sir Bleoberis overthrew him and sore hath wounded him.

column2: Then was King Mark heavy thereof, and all the court.
column3: Then was King Mark heavy thereof, and all the court.

column2: When Sir Tristram heard of this he was ashamed and sore grieved; and then was he soon armed and on horseback, and Gouvernail, his servant, bare his shield and spear.
column3: When Sir Tristram heard of this he was ashamed and sore grieved; and then was he soon armed and on horseback, and Gouvernail, his servant, bare his shield and spear.

column2: And so as Sir Tristram rode fast he met with Sir Andred his cousin, that by the commandment of King Mark was sent to bring forth, an ever it lay in his power, two knights of Arthur's court, that rode by the country to seek their adventures.
column3: And so as Sir Tristram rode fast he met with Sir Andred his cousin, that by the commandment of King Mark was sent to bring forth, an ever it lay in his power, two knights of Arthur's court, that rode by the country to seek their adventures.

column2: When Sir Tristram saw Sir Andred he asked him what tidings.
column3: When Sir Tristram saw Sir Andred he asked him what tidings.

column2: So God me help, said Sir Andred, there was never worse with me, for here by the commandment of King Mark I was sent to fetch two knights of King Arthur's court, and that one beat me and wounded me, and set nought by my message.
column3: So God me help, said Sir Andred, there was never worse with me, for here by the commandment of King Mark one was sent to fetch two knights of King Arthur's court, and that one beat me and wounded me, and set nought by my message.

column2: Fair cousin, said Sir Tristram, ride on your way, and if I may meet them it may happen I shall revenge you.
column3: Fair cousin, said Sir Tristram, ride on your way, and if I may meet them it may happen I shall revenge you.

column2: So Sir Andred rode into Cornwall, and Sir Tristram rode after the two knights, the which one hight Sagramore le Desirous, and the other hight Dodinas le Savage.
column3: So Sir Andred rode into Cornwall, and Sir Tristram rode after the two knights, the which one hight Sagramore le Desirous, and the other hight Dodinas le Savage.

column2: CHAPTER XVI.
column3: CHAPTER sixteen.

column2: How Sir Tristram fought with two knights of the Round Table.
column3: How Sir Tristram fought with two knights of the Round Table.

column2: THEN within a while Sir Tristram saw them afore him, two likely knights. Sir, said Gouvernail unto his master, Sir, I would counsel you not to have ado with them, for they be two proved knights of Arthur's court.
column3: THEN within a while Sir Tristram saw them afore him, two likely knights. Sir, said Gouvernail unto his master, Sir, I would counsel you not to have ado with them, for they be two proved knights of Arthur's court.

column2: As for that, said Sir Tristram, have ye no doubt but I will have ado with them to increase my worship, for it is many day sithen I did any deeds of arms.
column3: As for that, said Sir Tristram, have ye no doubt but I will have ado with them to increase my worship, for it is many day sithen I did any deeds of arms.

column2: Do as ye list, said Gouvernail.
column3: Do as ye list, said Gouvernail.

column2: And therewithal anon Sir Tristram asked them from whence they came, and whither they would, and what they did in those marches.
column3: And therewithal anon Sir Tristram asked them from whence they came, and whither they would, and what they did in those marches.

column2: Sir Sagramore looked upon Sir Tristram, and had scorn of his words, and asked him again, Fair knight, be ye a knight of Cornwall?
column3: Sir Sagramore looked upon Sir Tristram, and had scorn of his words, and asked him again, Fair knight, be ye a knight of Cornwall?

column2: Whereby ask ye it? said Sir Tristram.
column3: Whereby ask ye it? said Sir Tristram.

column2: For it is seldom seen, said Sir Sagramore, that ye Cornish knights be valiant men of arms; for within these two hours there met us one of your Cornish knights, and great words he spake, and anon with little might he was laid to the earth.
column3: For it is seldom seen, said Sir Sagramore, that ye Cornish knights be valiant men of arms; for within these two hours there met us one of your Cornish knights, and great words he spake, and anon with little might he was laid to the earth.

column2: And, as I trow, said Sir Sagramore, ye shall have the same handsel that he had.
column3: And, as I trow, said Sir Sagramore, ye shall have the same handsel that he had.

column2: Fair lords, said Sir Tristram, it may so happen that I may better withstand than he did, and whether ye will or nill I will have ado with you, because he was my cousin that ye beat. And therefore here do your best, and wit ye well but if ye quit you the better here upon this ground, one knight of Cornwall shall beat you both.
column3: Fair lords, said Sir Tristram, it may so happen that I may better withstand than he did, and whether ye will or nill I will have ado with you, because he was my cousin that ye beat. And therefore here do your best, and wit ye well but if ye quit you the better here upon this ground, one knight of Cornwall shall beat you both.

column2: When Sir Dodinas le Savage heard him say so he gat a spear in his hand, and said, Sir knight, keep well thyself: And then they departed and came together as it had been thunder.
column3: When Sir Dodinas le Savage heard him say so he gat a spear in his hand, and said, Sir knight, keep well thyself: And then they departed and came together as it had been thunder.

column2: And Sir Dodinas' spear brast in-sunder, but Sir Tristram smote him with a more might, that he smote him clean over the horse-croup, that nigh he had broken his neck.
column3: And Sir Dodinas' spear brast in sunder, but Sir Tristram smote him with a more might, that he smote him clean over the horse croup, that nigh he had broken his neck.

column2: When Sir Sagramore saw his fellow have such a fall he marvelled what knight he might be.
column3: When Sir Sagramore saw his fellow have such a fall he marvelled what knight he might be.

column2: And he dressed his spear with all his might, and Sir Tristram against him, and they came together as the thunder, and there Sir Tristram smote Sir Sagramore a strong buffet, that he bare his horse and him to the earth, and in the falling he brake his thigh.
column3: And he dressed his spear with all his might, and Sir Tristram against him, and they came together as the thunder, and there Sir Tristram smote Sir Sagramore a strong buffet, that he bare his horse and him to the earth, and in the falling he brake his thigh.

column2: When this was done Sir Tristram asked them: Fair knights, will ye any more?
column3: When this was done Sir Tristram asked them: Fair knights, will ye any more?

column2: Be there no bigger knights in the court of King Arthur? it is to you shame to say of us knights of Cornwall dishonour, for it may happen a Cornish knight may match you.
column3: Be there no bigger knights in the court of King Arthur? it is to you shame to say of us knights of Cornwall dishonour, for it may happen a Cornish knight may match you.

column2: That is truth, said Sir Sagramore, that have we well proved; but I require thee, said Sir Sagramore, tell us your right name, by the faith and troth that ye owe to the high order of knighthood.
column3: That is truth, said Sir Sagramore, that have we well proved; but I require thee, said Sir Sagramore, tell us your right name, by the faith and troth that ye owe to the high order of knighthood.

column2: Ye charge me with a great thing, said Sir Tristram, and sithen ye list to wit it, ye shall know and understand that my name is Sir Tristram de Liones, King Meliodas' son, and nephew unto King Mark. Then were they two knights fain that they had met with Tristram, and so they prayed him to abide in their fellowship.
column3: Ye charge me with a great thing, said Sir Tristram, and sithen ye list to wit it, ye shall know and understand that my name is Sir Tristram de Liones, King Meliodas' son, and nephew unto King Mark. Then were they two knights fain that they had met with Tristram, and so they prayed him to abide in their fellowship.

column2: Nay, said Sir Tristram, for I must have ado with one of your fellows, his name is Sir Bleoberis de Ganis.
column3: Nay, said Sir Tristram, for I must have ado with one of your fellows, his name is Sir Bleoberis de Ganis.

column2: God speed you well, said Sir Sagramore and Dodinas.
column3: God speed you well, said Sir Sagramore and Dodinas.

column2: Sir Tristram departed and rode onward on his way.
column3: Sir Tristram departed and rode onward on his way.

column2: And then was he ware before him in a valley where rode Sir Bleoberis, with Sir Segwarides' lady, that rode behind his squire upon a palfrey.
column3: And then was he ware before him in a valley where rode Sir Bleoberis, with Sir Segwarides' lady, that rode behind his squire upon a palfrey.
